Nevember 16, 1949
about that.
While I was trying to think up one of those bon nots which usully
come to you riding home fron the meeting in a taxi, Bondy naively asked how they
would secure service.
In the silence which followed that comment I managed to
suggest that this difficulty was atrietly Chinese and therefore we would prefer
not to be a party to the action.
They then said that they had just held a
meeting of the shareholders (they hold 80% of the stock)
and fired the Managing
Director as such and also as a Direetor and then introduced us to the new dir-
ectora - most of whom looked suspiciously like clerks or office stooges.
They
then announced that Generel Shen (a former Managing Director) had been appointed
Managing Director and wanted to know what we thought of thet.
It happens that he
is a good man, but we have never been consulted in the meny such changes which
have occurred.
The following day we - Bond, Allison and I - had a meeting with a
committee of the GNAC employees.
They claimed to represent 95% of the flight
and ground staff and announced that they would not take orders from the new Man-
aging Director nor would they permit any compeny-ored airplanes to fly to Nation-
alist held territory - what little there is left.
Furthermore,
they hinted very
broadly that certain parts had been removed fron the forty CNAC airplanes still
remaining on the Hongkong airport, and that it wouldn't be a good idea to fly or
try to fly any of them away.
We tried to talk the staff into a compromise - one
where the company would fly to Nationalist territory as well as Calcutta,
the
U,S.A, and Formosa with the understanding that none of the plenes would be held
in Nationalist arens and none would go over to the Reds, but the staff would not
agree.
It would be unsafe to fly without such agreement because of sebotage.
The
staff said that the Communists, or rather the "People's Government" as they call
it, had expressed the greatest concern over the safety of all us Americens and a
greet desire to have our continued participation in the operstions of CNAC. Fur-
thermore,
they promised that the "People's Governmentâ„¢ would advance enough money
every month to meet all expenses including the saleries of all American flight
and ground personnel.
(Theyll have & chance to make good on that promise at
the end of Novenber 1)
Next the Hongkong police put a guard on all airplenes.
The Chinese Civil Aeronsuties Administration cancelled all licenses.
The Op-
erations Department drained all gesoline (as fire prevention) frow the tanks, and
so it looks as though the remaining airplanes are really grounded.
The trouble within CNAC is just a small repetition of the trouble in China,
and we are as unable to cure the one as we are the other.
One of these days
Chungking will fall - then Kunming and then Formoss (which until the peace treaty
is still Japanese territory) alone will remin.
Khether Chiang Kai-shek and his
hangers-on will try to hold formosa against strikes, insurrections, sabotage and
Commnist infiltration -
if not sctual invasion - or whether he and his cohorts
will divide up the considerable Central Bank of China reserves and slip away to
some country
willing to harbor them remains to be seen.
One thing is sure,
Chiang
Kai-shek and his party have forfeited not only the ability to rule but also the
right
rule.
Unfortnately,
the people have no choice but the Communiets and
there is no doubt but that a very large majority are for the new regime - not
because of
Communism but in spite of it - and on the thory that any form ofgor-
erment
is better than what they have had.
some of you will renember
0. H. (Fatty)
send us presents
such as the sailors buy
red dregons
embroidered
on them 1
